speaker: Mark J. Parrell
title: President & Chief Executive Officer at Equity Residential
msg:
Yeah, well, I mean, we do intend to grow the development engine we hope will create some growth. We're open to the suggestion you made. It's again finding things to buy. If there were, it was a lot to buy out there, Michael, and we might be very interested in using debt. We have a lot of debt capacity, maybe a little bit of equity and start buying. We'd love to get bigger, that's, we think this is a great time to be any apartment business and we'd love to have both asset and cash flow growth. We will get a lot of cash flow growth from just the existing business.

So I'd tell you on both your very good questions. The limiter is more our opportunity set, not us wanting to pull those levers. We will pull the JV lever, we will pull the equity lever if there was a lot of great things to buy. With it being such a tough market to acquire in, the trading activity has been probably a better way for us to go.

speaker: Michael Bilerman
title: Analyst at Smith Barney Citigroup
msg: Right. And then just, I think that EQR's history as they've gone, as your company has gone through different times of market repositioning going back to the 2000s and then obviously to start with deal pre-pandemic that put the company into the six core markets. I guess, are you thinking at all about the larger transaction and I know it has to be available for you, but at least relative to some other times you have culminated the market repositioning with a large, a much larger transaction versus the sort of just year-by-year methodology.

speaker: Mark J. Parrell
title: President & Chief Executive Officer at Equity Residential
msg: We will react to the opportunity set that present itself. I mean I appreciate the comment because you're right, we are transactionalist. We're good at doing large deals. We know how to integrate assets 50 at a time or more into the portfolio. But again, I don't see that opportunity set out there. So I guess it's hard to react in the abstract to that. But I'd rather be done with this process, that part I agree with you. EQR would rather be done with the realignment process, but we're not in such a hurry that we'll do it by buying lower quality assets.

speaker: Michael Bilerman
title: Analyst at Smith Barney Citigroup
msg: Okay, great. See you in Florida.

speaker: Mark J. Parrell
title: President & Chief Executive Officer at Equity Residential
msg: See you there.

speaker: Operator
title: NA
msg: Thank you. We'll take our next question from Joshua Dennerlein with Bank of America.

speaker: Joshua Dennerlein
title: Analyst at Bank of America
msg: Yeah. Hey, guys. I just wanted to ask about a follow-up to an earlier comment where you spoke about same-store guidance ranges, and you mentioned trend intra-period rate growth. Can you just remind me what -- kind of how to think about trend intra-period rate growth is in the seasonality?

speaker: Michael L. Manelis
title: Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer at Equity Residential
msg:
Yeah. So if you think about kind of, and I'll use maybe 2018-2019 is like typical, right? So typical for this business kind of trend would have been something you know in the high twos, low threes in terms of rent growth and it tends to start -- you start a little bit in the first quarter, you build in the second quarter at the beginning of leases and you peak at the third quarter and then you typically have a little bit of a sequential rent decline as you get to the fourth quarter. So that would be typical kind of pricing trend as you looked in other years, right?

Now from a revenue standpoint, you're obviously not going to capture all of that because we talked about, you don't write all your leases on one-one. You have -- you may be capture half of it based on what I outlined in terms of actual revenue performance in a given year. So that's kind of what I think about of in terms of trend. What we've assumed in our '22 guidance is that we follow that kind of the same shape of the curve, but that it's a little bit above trend, right? That we continue to see that strength and it is a little bit higher than trend. If that is much above trend, right? As something that is approaching more like the mid single digits or even above, that's going to push your guidance range -- your guidance results to the or your actual results to the high end of the guidance range. If you're below that, call it, three that I would say in trend and you got kind of no growth that will push you down towards the bottom end of the range.

speaker: Joshua Dennerlein
title: Analyst at Bank of America
msg: Okay, that's really helpful. I appreciate that. And then that 25 basis points drag from capital recycling, is that just a function of timing or maybe a difference in cap rates across like buying and selling?

speaker: Mark J. Parrell
title: President & Chief Executive Officer at Equity Residential
msg: Yeah, it's Mark. It's kind of just in our model. It can be either one. But like this year, we didn't have any and our goal with Alex is to not have any again for it to be accretive, but it could be from either. It can be from selling early in the year and thus having more disposition NOI gone or it could be from buying early in the year and having more accretion just by virtue of that. So either or I guess I'd tell you.

speaker: Joshua Dennerlein
title: Analyst at Bank of America
msg: Okay.

speaker: Mark J. Parrell
title: President & Chief Executive Officer at Equity Residential
msg: You just take 25 basis points, multiply it by $2 billion, that's the negative drag somewhere [Technical Issues] this activity.

speaker: Joshua Dennerlein
title: Analyst at Bank of America
msg: Okay, awesome. Sounds like a potential source of upside of last year [Indecipherable]. So I'm reading it correctly. Thanks guys.

speaker: Mark J. Parrell
title: President & Chief Executive Officer at Equity Residential
msg: Thank you.

speaker: Operator
title: NA
msg: Thank you. It appears there are no further questions at this time. I'd like to turn the call back to Mr. Mark Parrell for any additional or closing remarks.

speaker: Mark J. Parrell
title: President & Chief Executive Officer at Equity Residential
msg: Well, thank you all for your time today. We look forward to seeing many of you in person at the conferences that are coming up and in your offices over the next few months. Thank you very much. Stay well.

speaker: Operator
title: NA
msg: [Operator Closing Remarks]
